docs.abstract: Mr. Williams, who also starred in “Boardwalk Empire” and “Lovecraft Country,” was best known for his role as Omar Little in the David Simon HBO series.
docs.snippet: Mr. Williams, who also starred in “Boardwalk Empire” and “Lovecraft Country,” was best known for his role as Omar Little in the David Simon HBO series.
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael K. Williams, the actor who brought a hard-edge charisma to his portrayal of Omar Little, the sawed-off-shotgun-wielding stickup man on the pioneering HBO series “The Wire,” was found dead on Monday in his home in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn. He was 54.

headline.main: Michael K. Williams, Omar From ‘The Wire,’ Is Dead at 54
headline.print_headline: Michael K. Williams, 54, ‘The Wire’ Star Who Embodied Edgy Charisma, Dies

byline.original: By Julia Jacobs, Annie Correal, Matthew Haag and Jeremy Egner

docs.abstract: Long sidelined, these narratives are ascendant in the culture, and offer an elastic yet demanding view of what it might take for Americans — and their nation — to heal.
docs.snippet: Long sidelined, these narratives are ascendant in the culture, and offer an elastic yet demanding view of what it might take for Americans — and their nation — to heal.
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR ALL THAT was emotionally sobering about the last year, it was literally sobering, too. Many Americans, drinking more than ever during Covid-19 lockdowns and with plenty of time to reflect on it, began to wonder if alcohol was more hindrance than help. The question had been popularized by the sober-curious movement, based on a term coined by the British author Ruby Warrington, and supported by online recovery programs such as Tempest, founded in 2014. But it became especially acute as the incoherent national response to the Covid-19 pandemic conspired with a failing health care system to prove once again that the state could not be trusted to ensure its citizens’ wellness. This was particularly true, the reanimated Black Lives Matter movement announced, when those citizens were brown or Black.

headline.main: The Black Recovery Stories Speaking to Individual and Collective Wellness

byline.original: By Emily Lordi, David Leggett and Shadi Al-Atallah

docs.abstract: This composer’s music — improvisatory, open to influence, personal yet resonant — will be hard to miss in the coming season.
docs.snippet: This composer’s music — improvisatory, open to influence, personal yet resonant — will be hard to miss in the coming season.
docs.lead_paragraph: The history of classical music in the United States is one long identity crisis: the search for a homegrown sound, free from European influence. That anxiety has manifested itself time and again as self-sabotage, with some composers — almost always white men — exalted as pathbreakers, while truly original work coming from artists of color has been overlooked.

headline.main: The Changing American Canon Sounds Like Jessie Montgomery
headline.print_headline: The Embodiment Of a Changing Canon

docs.abstract: In Thursday night’s season opener, players stood on the field at Raymond James Stadium with their arms intertwined as Alicia Keys and the Florida A&M choir performed “Lift Every Voice and Sing” before the game’s start.
docs.lead_paragraph: In Thursday night’s season opener, players stood on the field at Raymond James Stadium with their arms intertwined as Alicia Keys and the Florida A&M choir performed “Lift Every Voice and Sing” before the game’s start.

headline.main: The N.F.L. will keep playing the Black national anthem before games.

docs.abstract: Two unanimous rulings allow Gov. Ralph Northam to remove the statue from its prominent spot on Monument Avenue in Richmond.
docs.snippet: Two unanimous rulings allow Gov. Ralph Northam to remove the statue from its prominent spot on Monument Avenue in Richmond.
docs.lead_paragraph: Virginia’s Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously affirmed the power of Gov. Ralph Northam to remove an imposing statue of Robert E. Lee in Richmond, a symbol that had become a target of demonstrators after the death of George Floyd last year.

headline.main: Virginia Supreme Court Clears Path for Removal of Robert E. Lee Statue

docs.abstract: Votes on Tuesday involve the Sonoma County district attorney and two city council members in Vernon.
docs.snippet: Votes on Tuesday involve the Sonoma County district attorney and two city council members in Vernon.
docs.lead_paragraph: While all eyes were on Gov. Gavin Newsom, a developer in Sonoma County was charging forward with an effort to recall the district attorney who had sued his company.

headline.main: In California, there are recall attempts for everything under the sun.

docs.abstract: Theater seems to be responding to demands for diversity. Artists are both delighted and worried about the precarious moment in which the gates have opened.
docs.snippet: Theater seems to be responding to demands for diversity. Artists are both delighted and worried about the precarious moment in which the gates have opened.
docs.lead_paragraph: Broadway’s prepandemic theater season featured two plays by Black writers, and one of them had been kicking around since 1981. The previous season, there was one such play, and the season before that, zero.

headline.main: Broadway Is Brimming With Black Playwrights. But for How Long?

docs.abstract: While legislation in Washington remains stalled, state and local governments are breathing new life into the reparations movement.
docs.snippet: While legislation in Washington remains stalled, state and local governments are breathing new life into the reparations movement.

headline.main: Reparations for Black Residents Are Becoming a Local Issue as Well as a National One
headline.print_headline: Interest Grows in Making Reparations to Black Residents at Local Level

docs.abstract: Augustus, laden with championship rings and now an assistant with the Los Angeles Sparks, first realized her true strength fighting for L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
docs.snippet: Augustus, laden with championship rings and now an assistant with the Los Angeles Sparks, first realized her true strength fighting for L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
docs.lead_paragraph: The first time Seimone Augustus realized what she was capable of wasn’t when, as a 14-year-old, she landed on the cover of Sports Illustrated for Women next to the question, “Is She the Next Michael Jordan?”

headline.main: Seimone Augustus Found Her Voice Long Before Coaching
headline.print_headline: A W.N.B.A. Stalwart Found Her Voice Long Before Coaching

docs.abstract: Terry Albury, an idealistic F.B.I. agent, grew so disillusioned by the war on terror that he was willing to leak classified documents — and go to prison for doing it.
docs.snippet: Terry Albury, an idealistic F.B.I. agent, grew so disillusioned by the war on terror that he was willing to leak classified documents — and go to prison for doing it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of Aug. 29, 2017, Terry Albury awoke with a nagging sense of foreboding. It was not yet dawn in Shakopee, Minn., the Minneapolis suburb where Albury, an F.B.I. special agent, lived with his wife and two young children, and he lay in bed for a few minutes, running through the mental checklist of cases and meetings and phone calls, the things that generally made him feel as if his life was in order. He was a 16-year veteran of the F.B.I.: 38, tall and powerfully built, with buzzed black hair and a black goatee. Most of his career he had spent in counterterrorism, investigating sleeper cells and racking up commendations signed by the F.B.I. directors Robert Mueller and James Comey, which praised his “outstanding” work recruiting confidential sources and exposing terrorist financing networks. He was a careful investigator and a keen observer. “Something is going on behind the scenes that I’m not aware of,” he told his wife the night before. She told him to stop worrying. “You always think there’s something going on.” She was right. But this time he had reason to be apprehensive, even though he’d been careful. The memory card was buried in his closet, tucked into a shirt pocket under a pile of clothes. “Stop being so paranoid,” he told himself. Then he left for work.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
